newsitem.title: SPAIN: SOCCER-BETIS SHAKE UP SPANISH HIERARCHY.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BETIS SHAKE UP SPANISH HIERARCHY.

text.p: In the past the Real Madrid-Real Betis fixture scheduled for Saturday used to be a David and Goliath-style clash in which the only question really in doubt was the number of goals by which the home side would win.
But in the last few years Betis, together with Deportivo Coruna, have shaken up the hierarchy of the Spanish game and are no longer to be taken so lightly.
Betis have emerged perhaps not as kings, but at least as pretenders to the throne in this year's Spanish title race.
It is an unlikely role for the Seville-based side that for many years had to play second fiddle not just to the Madrid and Barcelona sides, but also to neighbours Sevilla.
Whereas the name of Real Madrid is almost synonymous in Spain with wealth, success and power, that of Real Betis is more readily identified with frustation and heroic failure.
Not that it bothered Betis' flamboyant following. They continued to pack the Benito Villamarin stadium even when the side were in the third division.

Whereas Sevilla traditionally monopolise the support of the city's wealthier classes, Betis tend to find their fans amongst the poorer sections of the community, amongst them Seville's famous gypsy clans.
Betis is also the favourite side of many flamenco musicians and bullfighters.
But all too often Betis's performance on the field would have been enough to inspire a 'cante jondo', or 'deep song', a wailing flamenco lament.
But after several years in the second division in which Betis looked likely to disappear under a sea of debt, the club has hit a more up-beat rhythm.
Conducted by owner Manuel Ruiz de Lopera and Serra Ferrer, who after over 100 games in charge is the Spanish first division's longest serving manager, Betis have reappeared with a vengeance.
A self-made multi-millionaire who once sold caps and scarves at Betis matches, Lopera has given the club the financial backing it never had in the past.
He spent over 3 billion pesetas ($21.1 million) over the summer in players, amongst them former Real Madrid striker Alfonso Perez.
Lopera's next signing, Ajax winger Finidi George, was widely interpreted as a snub to the Madrid side because of the problems they had caused in the Alfonso transfer.
Just this week Lopera has confirmed that he doesn't like taking a back seat in dealing with Spain's big two.
"If they're not good enough for Barcelona, they're not good enough for Betis," he said in response to reports that Barcelona may offer reserve players in exchange for the much-coveted Alfonso.
And he has big ideas for the future.
Lopera is reluctant to join Sevilla in plans for a new athletics stadium which would form the centrepiece of Seville's bid for the 2004 Olympics.
Instead he has asked architects for proposals for a new 70,000 all-seater venue of his own.
And while financially-troubled Sevilla are nose-diving toward the second division, Lopera's Betis could yet open their new stadium with a European Champions' League game.
